text: in January the Supreme Court eliminated
some restrictions on corporate and union
political spending critics warn that the
decision would open the floodgates for
special interest spending and swamp the
November midterm elections so far
corporations haven't rushed to produce
political ads themselves instead
corporations and individuals are
continuing to funnel money to
independent groups many of which are
nonprofits set up under a section of the
tax code these corporate and individual
donors can generally remain anonymous
which may explain their attraction to
the nonprofit's much of the recent
activity in this area has been on the
Republican side many of these nonprofit
groups have made the same kinds of
so-called issue ads that were legal even
before the supreme court ruling issue
ads tend to refrain from explicit calls
to vote for or against a candidate and
this restraint may help the group stave
off regulation by the IRS or the Federal
Election Commission and preserve the
anonymity of their donors tell Barbara
Boxer californians need jobs not bigger
deficits the US Chamber of Commerce is
responsible for the content of this
advertising but lately some nonprofits
have been more aggressive on Election
Day take the right path vote against
Chad Edwards American Future Fund is
responsible for the content of this
advertising these ads explicitly ask
voters to cast their ballots for or
against candidates it remains to be seen
whether this Express advocacy will draw
scrutiny from either the IRS or the
Election Commission
